text: a witness named in the notice heretofore filed, being of lawful age and having been first duly sworn, testified on his oath as follows: E X A M I N A T I O N

Good afternoon, Mr. Combs.  We met briefly off the record before the deposition.  My name is Rick Atwood.  I'm an attorney for the shareholders in litigation involving the Berkshire acquisition of Precision Castparts. Did you participate in the drafting of the merger proxy that went to Precision Castparts shareholders in connection with their vote on the merger?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I wouldn't say I participated in it.  I reviewed it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you review it before it was final?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I reviewed it before it went public, but I can't say -- I mean, nothing changed after I looked at it, to my knowledge.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall how it is that you came to be reviewing a draft of the proxy?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I don't remember who sent it over to me, but just in the normal course of business, it got sent to me.  It said, Take a look at it, review it. Let me know if anything should be changed or anything is different than your recollection.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you provide any responsive comments?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: No.  And everything checked out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. When did you start with Berkshire?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Late 2010, early 2011.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at the time you started, did Berkshire have any investment in Precision?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you initiated that position?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Ah, I believe 2012, if I remember correctly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall -- was it set up as a purchase of shares on the open market?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: It was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall how many shares you purchased?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I don't.  I don't remember how many shares. We ended up owning maybe 3, 3 and a half percent of the company, if I remember correctly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall what you paid for your initial investment in Precision?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Oh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In terms of per share?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Right.  I would be guessing, but I think it is an approximate guess, it would be about $150 a share.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall, as Berkshire added to its position over time, the prices -- the range of prices that it paid per share?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I don't remember the range.  But we didn't add that much after the initial purchase.  It was mostly done all at once.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So virtually the full 3 to 3 and a half percent was that the first investment?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Right.  To my recollection.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why did you choose to invest in Precision?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: It was a great company.  It had a great track record, with a great management team.  And it was well positioned in the aerospace business, and I thought it was relatively inexpensive at $150 a share.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of investigation did you do before making the purchase?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: So I'd say there was both quantitative and qualitative.  On the quantitative side, you look at the history, whether it is Value Line, Morningstar, you look at the performance.  The operating margins by individual business lines to see if there is anything aberrant or one time or cyclical, speculative, that kind of thing. Then on the qualitative side, we spent a lot of time doing what are often times referred to as channel checks, talking to customers, suppliers, ex-employees, et cetera, to gain a better understanding of what -- how the numbers come about, what the mode of the business is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did that process take before you made the purchase?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, that is hard to say because in this instance, we were doing checks on the aerospace industry as well, and so the two morphed. But to give an approximate timeline, it might have been somewhere between 3 to 6 months, as best I can recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who worked on that with you?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I had an analyst, Liz Barney.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is she still here?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did she leave?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: She left last year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know where she is now?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes, she's at a firm called -- oh, I will have to think of it.  I'm blanking on it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall why she left?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: She had been with me for eight years, and, you know, there was really no option -- she was an analyst for me.  She primarily did channel checks. You know, she wasn't going to move into a portfolio management role or anything like that, and so where she went to, she is in that role.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you happy with her work?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.  She was a good analyst.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to mark as exhibit next in order, it is a one-page email.  It is marked Confidential.  The Bates stamp is BH-PCC-0001448.  It is from Stacy Gottschalk. It is from March of 2015. If the court reporter can please mark it and hand it to the witness.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: (The referred-to document was marked by the court reporter for Identification as Deposition Exhibit 147.)
Have you ever seen this document before?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is it?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: These are -- I believe this is a note to myself in my calendar.  I was putting in a call, probably to Jay Khetani, who was the investor relations person for Precision at the time.  I had never spoken, as it points out, to Mark and the stock had fallen.  And I was reading some transcripts where Mark had been at some investor conferences and he sounded frustrated.  And so I was making some notes to myself and saved it in my calendar, reached out to Jay, and wanted to speak to Mark, wanted to set up a meeting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So were these notes of things that you intended to say once you had the conversation or things that you said after the conversation?  Notes of what you had sent?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Before.  These would have been notes that I gave to myself, you know, to talk to Mark beforehand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you actually get a chance to talk with him?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Not -- not on this date at this time, no. I spoke to Jay, who said that, as I recall, that, and he said that he passed my thoughts and comments on to -- on to Mark.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So when is the first time you had direct communication with Mr. Donegan?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Direct communication would have been, as best I can recall, is when he came out to Omaha in June, I believe it was. I don't think it was him that called me back to set it up.  I think Jay emailed with some dates.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I note the reference to "recruiting firm" here in this exhibit.  It is the very last item.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is that about?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: You know, there were -- well, he was -- he was -- Mark was clearly frustrated on some calls. As I referenced before, we do a lot of channel checks.  There were plenty of ex-employees out in the industry.  I can't remember whether it was one of them or another asset management firm. Somewhere -- someone somewhere along the line had mentioned that they -- and this is just gossip, it was never verified -- that -- that Mark may or may not have been talking to a recruiting firm. So this was a note to myself to make sure that he was going to be there, because he was a core part of the thesis in managing the company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever hear that he had been planning to retire from the company toward the end of 2015?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Not at this time, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you subsequently hear that?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I said -- I didn't -- not that unequivocally.  I had heard rumors.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever ask him about it?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I didn't.  No, I didn't ask him because I feel -- by the time that I heard that, I knew Mark well enough to know, and we had had enough conversations about his future at Berkshire and his commitment to the company when we did the acquisition, that I wasn't concerned about it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As a result of those conversations, you were --
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I felt confident that he would be around, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then just above that it says, "Just want you to know that not only do you have our full support, but I can unequivocally state that we only own the shares because of your presence." What did you mean by that?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yeah.  And hence the reference to recruiting firm under.  I wouldn't go so far as to say that I was baiting him, but what I was doing was seeing -- you know, no -- the CEO is not in a fiduciary position to tell if they were looking, necessarily. So I wanted to put him in somewhat of an awkward position to say, hey, look, we love the company, keep doing exactly what you are doing, don't make any short-term decisions.  We are going to be here, we are long-term supporters, and by the way, you are an important piece of that, just to see what his reaction was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever get a chance to communicate that to him?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: When he came out in June, I'm sure I did, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall that conversation or how it went?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I don't recall the specifics of it, but what I would say is that I recall, from that June meeting, would be that he showed unwavering commitment to the company, which is pretty much what you would expect a CEO to say. I felt -- I believed him and I felt confident that he was going to be there for the long term.  But that is exactly what I would have expected to him to say, too.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you communicate to him the notion that you were invested in the company because of his presence?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I'm sure I did, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So was this a meeting where part of it was without Mr. Buffett and part of it was with Mr. Buffett?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall whether you communicated that sentiment in the without Mr. Buffett part or the with Mr. Buffett part?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: That would have been probably without -- without Warren, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who else was there at that meeting?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, as I can recall, it would have been myself, Mark, I think Shawn and probably Jay.  Shawn Hagel, the CFO.  So the three of them were on one side of the table; I was on the other.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you first start mulling over the concept of acquiring the company outright?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, I would say, you know, these things are always gray, right?  Because there is no black and white.  But I would say that when they came out here and we discussed -- we discussed really the company in June.  And so I guess the best way I can answer your question is when I then subsequently reached out to Mark, and it was after that meeting in June.  So it would have been some time around the 4th of July, as best I recall. And that is when I kind of extended an olive branch, so to speak, to say, hey, we loved the meeting, we love the company.  All of these things reiterated, if you ever want to do something with us, let me know, and we can proceed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So did the -- did the concept, at least from your perspective, of maybe buying the company outright occur between that meeting and that call?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.  The purpose of that meeting was twofold in my mind. One, I had never met Mark, so it was to get to know him, get a better read on him.  I already knew the company, so there wasn't anything they really told me that I didn't know, that I can recall.  And it was to get Warren to meet Mark, and to get to know the company a little bit better, which, you know, we frequently do. And so after that, then, I had a couple of conversations with Warren, brought him up to speed. He asked some questions.  And that is when I reached out to Mark after talking to Warren to extend the olive branch.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you talk about the conversation with Mr. Buffett?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I'm sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The conversation that you just referenced with Mr. Buffett --
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- as that -- was there a discussion in that conversation about maybe buying the whole company?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I'm sure there was, yeah.  When I -- when I would have reached out to Mark, to extend the olive branch, it was only on Warren's authority.  It wouldn't have been on mine alone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there any discussion of a potential purchase price between you and Mr. Buffett during that time frame?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, that was -- things were still preliminary at that point.  So the stock was trading, as best I can recall, around 210.  You know, we probably said something to the fact that, you know, if you take a 20 percent premium that would put it around 250.  And I think I could have seen Warren saying something to the effect, well, it is -- maybe it takes X amount to get it done, but it was still very, very preliminary at that point. And so I took some notes.  I called Mark. I did not extend a price, because things were still very preliminary.  I just wanted to feel him out. And he said exactly what I would expected him to say, which is I will take it to my board as a fiduciary, et cetera, et cetera.  And so it wasn't until -- to answer your question, it wasn't until after Mark then came back and expressed some interest in proceeding and wanted to know a price, then we had to come up with a price.  And that is when we came up with the 235.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was the mechanism for coming up with the price?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, there is no formula or anything to it.  You know, Warren and I talked about the company, 95 percent of what we discussed in these things is qualitative.  And so he asked me what the key risk factors were.  We talked through the margins of the company, how consistent they had been.  How they had slowly trended up.  The dependence and reliance on aerospace, where we were in the cycle.  So it was a very qualitative discussion. And at the end of the day, you know, I use Morningstar; Warren uses Value Line, and, you know, he came up with a number.  And we discussed it, but he came up with it.  And, you know, there is no real formula to it or anything.  It is -- the stock had probably trailed off a bit by then to maybe 190 and change or something.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it a premium to the stock price like before?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any discussions with Mr. Buffett in the time frame leading up to making the offer about the acquisition's component of Precision Castparts's overall strategy?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I'm sorry.  Can you say it one more time? I'm not sure I followed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you read that back.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: (Thereupon, the requested portion was read back by the reporter as above recorded.)
Yes, so when you say "the acquisition's," you mean Precision making deals?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Correct.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It gets a little confusing.  We are talking about an acquisition involving acquisitions.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: That is why I wanted to make sure I was answering your question properly. No -- well, the only -- so going forward, no.  What Warren and I would have discussed is when we were looking at the historical numbers, I'm sure that he asked me how much was acquisition driven. And I would have walked him through, in fact, I even vaguely recall laying out, you know, by quarter, or by year how many deals they had done.  And we talked about most companies do not do deals very well.  And so that is -- it can sometimes be a red flag. And so, and you want to know whether a company has achieved their growth organically or through acquisition, through one big acquisition; lots of small acquisitions. We talked about it in a historical context, but not in a going forward context.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was the view of how Precision Castparts had performed in terms of its acquisition activity compared to some of the examples that you just mentioned?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yeah, I think given their track record overall, you don't really, really know, to be honest.  Because companies, you know, melded in. Most of their acquisitions were small, tuck-ins.  I remember Timet was one in particular that Mark and I did talk about when he came out, because they had just recently completed it.  And according to Mark, it had done well. But you don't really know from the outside looking in, almost with any acquisition, how it goes.  And you know the amalgamation, the results, but, you know, we have enough pattern recognition, looking at these things, our general sense that they had done pretty good.  You can look at good will write-offs and things like that.  Yeah, I don't -- yeah, I'm sure there were some hits and misses in there.  I think overall they had done okay. But they have a good core business, too. So...
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Berkshire expected Precision to continue on with its business plan including potential acquisitions of its own if the merger took place?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: You know, we didn't have that discussion. I think the expectation from us generally is that each of our managers, you know, the way we are structured, generally speaking, they generate a certain amount of cash, they have a necessary component to reinvest in the business, and we are the allocators of capital. And so whether it is -- any of our subsidiaries, small, medium or large, it is generally expected within some reasonable threshold that they come to us, because we are the allocators of capital. And so we never really had any kind of, I would say -- I think putting the term expectation on it would be too hard or too heavy.  There wasn't any kind of discussion of that. I think the general expectation was that they would continue to execute well in terms of the market share in the aerospace industry, and continued to gain a higher dollar component of -- with Boeing and Airbus and GE.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have conversations with anybody at Precision about their acquisitions strategy and continuing to get acquisitions even after the Berkshire merger?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Rick, could you -- I'm sorry.  Is your question directed at the period -- can you supply a time frame on when the conversation -- what conversations you are asking about?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Any time frame.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Ever?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Before or after the merger was completed, did you have conversations with people at Precision about Precision continuing its own acquisitions program as well?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes, I just want to make sure I understand the question. So after the acquisition, I certainly spoke to both Mark, and I believe his name is Kirk Pulley, who is his M & A guy on specific deals. And I want to be clear, there was not conversations about nebulously doing deals.  So in terms of expectations, or how much do you think you will be able to allocate this year, those kind of conversations didn't happen. But when Mark or Kirk had a specific deal, we would and still do discuss those.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And they are continuing to look for acquisitions for Precision?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yeah, I think so.  I mean, most of our managers do.  You never know when they will occur obviously, and particularly in this environment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I would like to mark exhibit next in order.  It is email chain between the witness and Elizabeth Barney.  It looks like it is from January 2015.  It is marked Confidential.  The HB-PCC-00003060 to 3063.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: (The referred-to document was marked by the court reporter for Identification as Deposition Exhibit 148.)
Do you want this back?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just keep a stack right there.
speaker: THE REPORTER

text: I have to go back to the beginning on this one. Okay.  I didn't read it word for word; I think I get the general gist of it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  My first question is, what is the purpose of this dialogue?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Uh-huh.  Well, it looks like they reported third quarter '15 earnings, and my analyst, for any company that she covers, and my current analyst, we have about a dozen names in the portfolio, and they -- the purpose is they literally update me on the earnings. And in this case, it looks like -- I'm just skimming it -- that Precision missed.  And so then it looks like the purpose is her explaining, and it looks like due to oil and gas, and so forth and so on, and there was some de-stocking taking place and so forth.  And so she was kind of explaining why they missed. And I normally follow up with some questions.  She would call the IR person, and I would make sure that I understand everything to be able to make a decision on it as a stock.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Whether to sell it or buy more?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Or just -- or just sit tight, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So on the first page there, in an email from her, she says, "I have a call into PCP. Summarized thinking for now," and she has several line items under that.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm trying to get an understanding of what it is -- what the exercise -- is this something that she did on her own or something that you asked her to do?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, she would -- this is the expectation for the job is to any -- any name that is in the portfolio, of which Precision was at the time, she just knew, this is -- this is what I do.  I cover a name and if they beat, they missed, nothing happened, here is what happened in the quarter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So when she says like they are under -- under the first item --
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- I think it is possible -- in sort of the middle -- I think it is possible that they could still grow their business, even in a down oil price environment because it is a market share gain game for them to some extent, but I'm taking full ax for now.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does that mean?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: That, as I recall, she -- the -- the hit that so -- so oil, and I'm going off memory here, oil prices got cut in half or something from 80 to 40 around this time period. We -- she had spent all of her time focused -- all of our time on the aerospace side. So the oil and gas side caught us by surprise.  It wasn't something that we had really talked to the company about. And so then when we started to get our arms around it, you know, I think she's saying here, that she's just basically writing off oil and gas at zero in terms of our intrinsic value analysis. Although, all else being equal, she's saying, they will gain share, et cetera, et cetera, but I'm not giving them any credit for that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Then she goes on to say, "Before the oil and gas situation, I liked the stock at 220.  So around 200, (where it looks like it make trade today), I like it." Like it for what purpose, did you have any understanding what she meant by that?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, she would have been saying -- although she had no buy, sell, or hold authority, she was just giving me her color in terms of, you know, at 200, she would like it.  And she probably either meant hold it or she would be okay buying more.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you agree or disagree with her analysis?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes, I generally agreed with her.  I generally agreed.  I don't recall fervently disagreeing or anything.  Most analysts, it is a forest through the trees thing.  So most analysts, when you are close to situation, you know, have a resistance on the way down. And so I felt like there was probably another shoe or two to drop.  But, you know, I didn't take her stock recommendations too heavily, she was -- but I wanted her opinion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, as far as the kind of analysis, analysis that she does here, do you do any similar analysis of your own?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Do you mean in general or for Precision?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, in general first.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: You know, I do my own analysis.  But, again, it is largely qualitative.  I'm a more back-of-the-envelope kind of guy.  I have been doing this long enough, that I don't run out big DCF models or anything on my own anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You used to, but not anymore?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: A long time ago.  Another life.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you do any DCF models for this particular acquisition?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anybody at Berkshire?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The third line item there, under Summarized Thinking, if you get the 19 --
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- 2018 times 14 plus 266, what do you understand that math to be signifying?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes, if they put $19 of earnings in '18, and a 14 PE multiple, you should multiple the two together, it is 266.  I didn't think they had 40 to 45 -- oh, she's saying 40 to 45 share in cash, which is what they would generate between 15 and 18.  So call that, you know, an average at 14, 15 bucks a year, or something like that. So she's trying to give me an idea of target price, call it 310 on 18.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any disagreement with her methodology or analysis there?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Not really, no.  No. I thought her 19 was probably -- I thought her 19 was probably too high.  She tended to be too high on the earnings and too low on the multiples. But, you know, you work with somebody long enough, you make these adjustments kind of intuitively.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: She goes on to say, "I will let you know when I speak with PCP"?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know if she ever had that conversation?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I'm sure she did because she was very thorough.  And she would have -- she would have sent a follow-up note, if she did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you recall seeing anything of significance coming out of that?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: No.  Probably some marginal color on oil and gas.  And at some point, you know, the stuff becomes so detailed, if you are already writing it off at zero or something, there wasn't anything that meaningful.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you mark as the exhibit next in order, it is an email from Elizabeth Barney to the witness, dated April 26th, 2015. There is an attachment.  The document is marked Confidential.  The Bates range is BH-PCCC-0002249 to 2253.  If the reporter can please mark it and hand it to the witness.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: (The referred-to document was marked by the court reporter for Identification as Deposition Exhibit 149.)
Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall this document?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Vaguely, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the purpose of this analysis?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, they had made a fair number of acquisitions, and we had done a fair number of -- as I had referenced, some channel checks, and I am thinking -- and the stock had -- you know, they had missed earnings a couple of times, the stock had sold off.  And so my nature kind of proclivity would be to go back and say, did we miss anything? And you would -- I would naturally start with their acquisitions.  And so I probably asked her to go back and take the last five largest acquisitions they did, which is what this looks like, and just kind of re-underwrite them and talk to some ex-employees, see how they were doing, and kind of lay it all out for me so that I had a better kind of framework to think through that, is what I'm think.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why did you say you would naturally start with the acquisitions?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I'm sorry?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why did you say you would naturally start with the acquisitions?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Because the aerospace side we had done all of the work on, and I remember being completely comfortable there.  And I follow lots of other aerospace companies.  And so I was perfectly fine there.  The oil and gas is kind of is what it is, was what it was.  And so there wasn't a lot of figure out there. And so the unknown in my mind was whether one of these acquisitions was causing an issue or not.  And they had allocated a fair amount of capital there over time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall any conclusion or answer to the question about those acquisitions?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.  It is interesting seeing this document again.  Not really.  Which is often times how research goes.  You try and kind of fill in the edges of the jigsaw puzzle and sometimes it is clearer than others. But relative to what my understanding was to begin with, it was interesting to see some of the numbers, and, you know, the purchase prices and so forth.  But, no, there wasn't anything that kind of created a red flag or anything to dig deeper in to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How do you go about finding ex-employees to do your channel checks?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Usually LinkedIn, or alumni networks, industry conferences.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who does the outreach for that?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: My analyst.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: They say, I'm calling from Berkshire and I want to know about Precision?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are people pretty forthcoming?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Or, there are -- "obfuscations" is too strong.  Generally, we wouldn't say we were calling Precision.  We would generally say we are calling about the aerospace industry.  Because we don't want to tip our hand necessarily.  We start kind of more vague and work our way in.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: People are pretty forthcoming in those outreaches?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Generally.  Generally.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I want to mark as exhibit next in order.  It is a single-page email chain marked Confidential.  The Bates range is BH-PCC-0000896.  It is from July 2nd, between the witness and Stacy Gottschalk.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: (The referred-to document was marked by the court reporter for Identification as Deposition Exhibit 150.)
Have your seen this document before?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes, I typed it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Tell me what it is.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: These are similar to the first note, notes to myself before calling Mark.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was this after you met with him?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this is in preparation for a call?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that call did happen?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how much of what is reflected here did you communicate to him?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Well, I didn't -- I did not reflect the 250 per share all cash.  I reflected -- and I can go into why -- I would have reflected all of this, and these are notes to myself, and probably, you know, the general concept that we like the company, we think it has a strong moat, you know, special company.  We would love for it to be part of Berkshire.  And, you know, we would be interested in presenting an offer.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you give a price when you had the call?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Not on this call, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where did the 250 come from that is reflected here?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I was in Warren's office, and I was taking notes.  We were talking about the company itself. And as I said, I think the 250 came from the stock. As I can best recall, it was probably around 2 to 210 at the time.  So at a 20-ish percent premium would have been about 250. And I don't remember exactly, but I could see Warren saying something to the effect of, you know, that is what it would take to get done. And Warren would have said, why don't you give him a call?  And give Mark a call and feel him out, would be how Warren would say it. And this was all incredibly tentative. You know, this was not a months long process; he had literally been in here just a couple of days before. And so two things, I remember distinctly going through my mind is one, this felt very, very early, and two, I didn't -- I thought -- well, three things.  Two, I thought, if we got to that point, Warren should be the one extending the offer, not me.  It would mean more to Mark coming from Warren than me. Three, or -- and back to one, it felt very, very early because we were still early in the process. Three, I had no idea how he would react. And I didn't want to put in a compromised position where I'm giving him a number, and then you cross a threshold at that point where he has to take it to his board.  Maybe it puts the company in play and so forth. And so I just felt like it was too early all around to do that.  And so I did not go there. And even if you feel the conversation out, and if it were in person -- and also Warren -- I mean, Warren did not know this company as well as he knows some other larger companies.  And so having worked with him already at this point for five years, I also had a pretty good feel for Warren's comfort level.  And Warren hadn't gone through my documents or my notes at this point. So I just kind of knew Warren well enough to know, like, hey, look, we don't have to rush with this.  We can give it a week.  And to my recollection, that is exactly what happened.  Mark said, I will take it to the board and I will come back to you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I would like to mark as exhibit next in order, it is some handwritten notes, marked, confidential.  The Bates range is BH-PCC-0000115.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: (The referred-to document was marked by the court reporter for Identification as Deposition Exhibit 151.)
Have you ever seen this plaintiff?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: It is my handwriting for sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Excuse me.  Wait for the question.
speaker: MR. GARVEY

text: Sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thanks.
speaker: MR. GARVEY

text: It is your handwriting.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall what this document is or why it was created?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: You know, I think to the best of my recollection, I don't have a date on it, and I normally date things, so that would help. But I was either doing it for myself, you know, we have -- I literally have hundreds and hundreds of pages on Precision.  You know, a big accordion folder.  So it is possible that it was done when I was looking at, you know, back to this Elizabeth Barney doing channel checks on the acquisitions, or it is possible that I laid this out for myself, to discuss with Warren on the acquisitions. These are clearly the acquisitions that -- that Precision had done, and roughly the timeline and the prices they had paid.  So you can see Timet, way up top, two and a half billion, 4/2/12, et cetera.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Composite Horizons and Noranco from 2015 are also on there, right?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes.  Yes.  So it was obviously done at least after that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall why or what you did with it?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: No.  I mean, I think it didn't really hold enough -- there wasn't anything regulatory out of any of this that is isn't in -- I was probably going through public documents, it looks like, because there are very specific numbers here in the middle, 848, 582, et cetera.  I was probably going through the Qs, and I have got 10-K marked over in kind of the left-hand column there to actually add up how much they spent on acquisitions. And just kind of laying out me, either for myself, or for Warren, you know, how much they had spent.  It is a little bit of a fruitless exercise because you don't know what the earnings are associated with -- with this.  But you know how much they spent, certainly over a three-year time horizon, most of which was Timet. So I think I was probably trying to frame either for myself, or Warren.  You know, you follow these names for a long time, sometimes they become clearer; sometimes parts of it become more fuzzy. There wasn't anything terribly regulatory out of it, that is for sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Below that it says break up/walk away and there is a language and then a dollar sign it looks like, do you see that?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And a reference to China, do you know what of refers?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Oh, well that -- I didn't see that before. I would say that would make me think that it was probably more for Warren and that it was during -- after we had made an offer.  And that -- if I'm making a note about this, I probably took these notes in on the acquisition, just to have them for Warren. Like, hey, they've spent $7 billion over three years, over a third of it was on Timet.  Here is their Timet-type thing.  And then these notes were probably either with Warren talking about the break up fee and, you know, language on walking away and getting approval from China.  It can always be challenging. Or with Munger Tolles, I can't assume or remember which.  Obviously, I didn't provide much -- much detail.  But I'm probably just making notes to myself at that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't we go off the record for a couple of minutes.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Stand by as we go off the record.  The time is approximately 2:10 p.m.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: (Thereupon, a recess was taken, after which the following proceedings were held:)
All right.  We are back on the record.  The time is approximately 2:12 p.m.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: Other than potential follow up to any subsequent questions, I think we are done. E X A M I N A T I O N
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: So Mr. Combs, as part of your responsibilities for Berkshire Hathaway, do you monitor the performance of Precision Castparts?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you do that on a regular basis, quarterly?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Sometimes monthly, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And during the period since January of 2016 --
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- when Berkshire closed the acquisition of Precision Castparts --
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- has the performance of Precision Castparts met the expectations that you had for its performance at the time you and Mr. Buffett were engaged in and ultimately completed the -- signed up the acquisition of Precision?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Unfortunately not.  You know, they had estimates -- we don't rely on forecasts, to be clear, but they had estimates in the proxy, there were forecasts that Mark provided, Shawn, and the management team to the board when he presented, and each of those forecasts, they have fallen short of for various reasons.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what are some of the reasons why Precision has fallen short of those forecasts that were provided to Berkshire and in the proxy?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Uh-huh.  Well, a myriad of reasons.  But certainly the margins have come in.  And you can -- you can't argue with the numbers. The core aerospace business has performed relatively in line, I would say.  It probably hasn't grown to the extent that we thought it would.  And then the other areas, they have certainly had some issues in fasteners, in Wyman Gordon and forged products and I believe in airframe products. So in an industrial company, when you have -- they call them incrementals on the positive side and decrementals on the negative.  And so those decrementals come through at a very, very high levels.  And so those margins, particularly in those lines of business, have hurt the company's overall performance.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you just explain for the record what you mean by a "decremental"?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Sure. When that dollar of revenue you lose on the top line in a high fixed cost business like an airline or something, it falls -- that dollar falls directly to the bottom line.  So rather if the business has a 10, 20, 30 percent margin, instead of falling at a 10, 20, 30 percent margin, it falls at a 100 percent margin. And so if you lose 10 or 20 percent top line in a fixed cost business, you have a massively outsized impact on the incremental margin.  Or it comes through in decrementals when it is negative.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is that fair description of what happened Precision in the period since Berkshire closed acquisition?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: That is a fair description of the output. And then my first part of the answer was hopefully answering the input as to why that was occurring.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  As part of your responsibilities at Berkshire Hathaway, do you monitor the acquisition activity by Precision?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Precision's acquisitions of other companies?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: I do.  Yes.  Mark and Kirk and I have met more than a handful of times on a potential acquisitions.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you aware any time Precision makes any acquisition before they go ahead and make it?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Generally speaking, yes.  I would be surprised -- I can't say with 100 percent certainty, but I would be surprised if an acquisition got done, and I didn't know about it, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there a threshold level above which they would be expected to come to you to talk about an acquisition?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Yes, we set an exact limit, which I cannot recall.  I want to say that it is a half billion dollars, but that could be wrong. Generally speaking, though, with all of our managers -- now if it were 10 or $20 million, I remember Mark and I talking about a -- I want to say it was either 30 or $60 million acquisition.  So Mark is great about reaching out, saying this is what I'm thinking. So -- it is a good relationship.  Neither one of us, and Warren included, you know, whatever that threshold is, we generally, as good partners, just discuss it, regardless of size.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the period since the closing of Berkshire's acquisition of Precision in January of 2016 --
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- so it has been three and a half years since then --
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- has Precision succeeded in adding value through acquisitions of its own and if it has, how much?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: And this is my opinion.  I think they have struggled in the -- on the acquisition side.  There have been a few duds in particular.  And look, it is -- their core business, you know, my understanding -- I never owned it for the acquisition.  I owned it because of their core position in the aerospace market.  And to some extent, you run into a law of large numbers at some point. And they have great market share where they are.  There aren't a lot of great acquisitions to make there.  And so almost by definition, the acquisitions you end up making end up being kind of around the fringes.  My opinion is that they have struggled a bit.  And they haven't made as many acquisitions either as they were here before.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have they made any acquisitions that did not produce any profit for the company?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Yes.  There was one in particular, it begins with an "S," it's over in Germany, Schultz or Schulls.  It has been a real bomb.  And it was not inexpensive.  I want to say it was 6 or 700 million. And, you know, it will probably end up being a complete writeoff.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You referred earlier to, in talking about acquisitions to -- when I mean "earlier," I mean in response, I think, to one of Mr. Atwood's questions, to Mr. Donegan coming to you to in effect approve or authorize an acquisition.
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you, since the closing of the Berkshire acquisition of Precision vetoed or refused approval to Mr. Donegan to proceed with an acquisition that he wanted to make?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: No.  No.  It is not our cultural style really to necessarily veto unless it is so, so extreme. We would try and dissuade our managers, certainly.  Hopefully, they would never bring anything that's six to 8 deviations.  We generally trying to work with them. I strongly dissuaded Mark, in particular, from the Schultz acquisition.  But, ultimately, it was -- it was his decision as the CEO.  And he decided, chose to go forward with that. And so, as I referenced earlier, we feel like we are not operators of businesses, as Warren has publicly stated.  We are capital allocators. And so some of our managers like to look at acquisitions, some don't.  And sometimes the ones who are looking shouldn't, and sometimes the ones who aren't, should.  And that is the nature of the beast. And so we give our opinion, and if it were a huge acquisition that were completely out of left field, we would veto it.  But it takes a very high threshold for us to get to that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that has not happened during the period of Berkshire's ownership of Precision?
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: No.  No. Mark and I had some discussions about acquisitions that I disagreed with, but -- but ultimately it was his call.  And a few of those probably have worked out.  The ones I'm aware of have not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have no further questions. F U R T H E R  E X A M I N A T I O N
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Was the Shultz acquisition one that is in litigation?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: It is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that is because Precision was defrauded by Schultz?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: I think that is their -- that is their contention, right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That is Precision's contention?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: That is Precision's contention.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has the company's performance been impacted by the 737 Max situation?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: It has a bit.  I mean, it is hard to tell because you don't get -- it is a little like acquisitions, it all gets rolled into the fold. But, yes, it would not be a positive, certainly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has the company's performance been impacted by continuing low oil and gas prices?
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Yes, I would say so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think that is it for us.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Nothing further.
speaker: MR. ROBERT BARON

text: Great.  Thank you, Mr. Combs.
speaker: MR. ATWOOD

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Please stand by.  This is the end of the deposition.  The time is approximately 2:22 p.m.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER
